Study: Preliminary Results of Seroprevalence of SARS-CoV-2 at Community Clinics in Tokyo
Excerpt: Suggests a higher population infected with COVID-19 in metropolitan Tokyo than the national survey

Study: Quantifying human mobility behavior changes in response to non-pharmaceutical interventions during the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.
Factors: Mobile Phone Data, Social Distance Index, COVID Cases
Excerpt: The SDI changes clearly indicate that people stay home more and travel less on weekends, especially on Sundays. People also become less attentive to the outbreak as the outbreak persists

Study: A reality check on the use of face masks during the COVID-19 outbreak in Hong Kong
Excerpt: In our study, 94·8% (n = 9683) wore masks of which 83·7% wore disposable surgical masks. However, 13·0% wore them incorrectly; with 35·5% worn ‘inside-out’ or ‘upside-down’; and 42·5% worn too low, exposing the nostrils or mouth.

Study: Non-compliance with COVID-19-related public health measures among young adults: Insights from a longitudinal cohort study
Excerpt: Young adults generally complied with COVID-19 public health measures, although compliance with some measures (e.g., cleaning/disinfecting mobile phones, standing 1.5-2 meters apart) was relatively lower. Non-compliance, especially with hygiene-related measures, was more prevalent in males, and in individuals with higher education, higher SES, and a nonmigrant background. Young adults with low trust, including in the government’s measures for fighting the virus, also complied less.

Study: Mapping the intercounty transmission risk of COVID-19 in New York State
Factors: COVID Cases, and Number of days until 100 cases
Excerpt: Areas with significant transportation connections to counties that had a high case load are at risk of becoming the next outbreak area.

Study: Modelling the role of media induced fear conditioning in mitigating post-lockdown COVID-19 pandemic: perspectives on India
Factors: COVID Cases, Mass Media Type, and Fear index
Excerpt: The present study suggests that, during post-lockdown phase, media induced fear conditioning in conjunction with closure of schools for about one more year can serve as an important non-pharmaceutical intervention to substantially mitigate this pandemic in India

Study: Agent-Level Pandemic Simulation (ALPS) for Analyzing Effects of Lockdown Measures
Factors: COVID Cases and Social Distancing Methods
Excerpt: The ALPS model  provides an efficient yet comprehensive modeling of the spread of infections in a self-contained community model. The model provides quantification of gains in reducing casualties by continued maintenance of restrictive measures in place.

Study: What are the Underlying Transmission Patterns of COVID-19 Outbreak? - An Age-specific Social Contact Characterization
Excerpt: Strict control of resumption of work is associated with less new cases compared to loose control.

Study: Timing of Community Mitigation and Changes in Reported COVID-19 and Community Mobility - Four U.S. Metropolitan Areas, February 26-April 1, 2020.
Factors: Cumulative number of reported COVID-19 cases, average 3-day percentage change in reported cases, community mobility, and public health intervention
Excerpt: As policies implemented increased the amount of people leaving home decreased; in all four localities the percentage leaving home was close to 80% on February 26, and by April 1 the percentage leaving home was 42% in New York City, 47% in San Francisco, 52% in Seattle, and 61% in New Orleans.
Measure of Evidence: cities: New York, New Orleans, San Franciso, Seattle

Study: Voluntary and Mandatory Social Distancing: Evidence on COVID-19 Exposure Rates from Chinese Provinces and Selected Countries
Excerpt: Mandating social distancing is very effective, but is costly in terms of employment loss. However, if targeted isolation towards individuals most likely to spread the infection, the employment loss and infection rate can be somewhat reduced

Study: Association of County-Level Socioeconomic and Political Characteristics with Engagement in Social Distancing for COVID-19
Factors: Average Distance Travelled by cell phone data
Excerpt: We find that lower per capita income and greater Republican orientation were associated with significantly reduced social distancing among U.S. counties

Study: Adoption of Personal Protective Measures by Ordinary Citizens during the COVID-19 Outbreak in Japan
Factors: Personal protective methods: hand hygiene, social distancing measures, avoiding touching the eyes, nose and mouth, respiratory etiquette, and self-isolation
Excerpt: Based on the loose standards, approximately 80% of participants implemented hand hygiene, respiratory etiquette, and self-isolation. However, 67.4% and 59.8% implemented social distancing measures and avoided touching the eyes, nose, and mouth, respectively. The prevalence of the loose and strict standards of implementation of all personal protective measures was 34.7% and 6.5%, respectively.

Study: Little Risk of the COVID-19 Resurgence on Students in China (outside Hubei) Caused by School Reopening
Factors: COVID-19 infections on students as transmitted from infected teachers
Excerpt: The probability of COVID-19 resurgence within one week on students of primary, 48 middle and high schools in China (outside Hubei) is extremely low (<0.2%)

Study: Exponential Phase of COVID19 Expansion is not Driven by Climate at Global Scale
Factors: COVID-19 expansion based on socioeconomic, climatic, and transportation predictors
Excerpt: A countries' importance in global air transportation network is the main explanation of different for the growth rate of COVID-19 in different countries, not socioeconomic status or climatic factors

Study: Impact of School Closures for COVID-19 on the US Health-Care Workforce and Net Mortality: a Modelling Study.
Factors: Modeling School Closures and Pathogen Induced Mortality
Excerpt: Our model estimates that school closures could lead to a greater number of deaths than they prevent and the potential contagion prevention from school closures needs to be carefully weighed with the potential loss of health-care workers.

Factors: Active Cases and Social Distancing Measures
Excerpt: Reductions in travel and the speed at which communities take action can play decisive roles in stopping the outbreak. The analysis suggests that for the coronavirus to be eliminated, it is not necessary to impose aggressive social distancing measures all over the world at once, but rather only in communities in which active spreading is detected

Study: Evaluation of the Effectiveness of Surveillance and Containment Measures for the First 100 Patients with COVID-19 in Singapore - January 2-February 29, 2020.
Excerpt: Singapore implemented aggressive measures to contain local transmission and number of cases declined after one month. As of March 5, 2020, schools have not closed because there was no widespread community transmission. To reduce community spread measures including: reducing mixing across classes or schools, public education messages were focused on personal hygiene and seeking early medical care and self-isolation were implemented.

Study: Compliance with COVID-19 Social-Distancing Measures in Italy: The Role of Expectations and Duration
Excerpt: When we asked respondents to assume that the government would extend the stay-at-home measures by a few weeks, 67.5% indicated that they would “continue with their current self isolation behavior”, 12.8% that they would increase it “to some extent”, 9.3% that they would increase it “greatly”, 8.3% that they would reduce it to some extent, and 2% said that they would “consider no longer respecting the rules”.
